I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The  transaction  technical  assistance  (TA)  facility  will  provide  project  preparation, 
implementation, and capacity building support for ensuing and ongoing regional cooperation and 
integration (RCI) projects in Mongolia and an approved multitranche financing facility (MFF) in the 
Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region (IMAR) of the People’s Republic of China (PRC). These RCI 
projects will strengthen the coordination between the two neighboring countries in addressing the 
cross-border development challenges, especially in tackling cross-border risks through efforts 
such as sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS) measures. Improving SPS measures to meet the 
international standards is essential to facilitate customs and border-crossing procedures, sustain 
inclusive growth, and foster economic diversification in Mongolia. The TA will expand regional 
public  goods  (RPGs)  by  supporting  cross-border  public  health  infrastructure  and  services 
(including SPS measures); mitigating transboundary public health risks; strengthening resilience 
to climate change; and integrating sustainable protection of ecosystems and the environment in 
the project design and implementation.1  
 
2.  Based  on  the  Staff  Instructions  on  MFF2 of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB), 
preparation of projects under the second and subsequent tranches is to be financed under the 
earlier tranches unless otherwise justified in the report and recommendation of the President.3 
Under the IMAR MFF, a provision is made for using TA funds for the preparation of the 
subsequent tranches when extensive safeguard or other due diligence requirements arise or 
changes occur during implementation. It is expected that several pre-identified subprojects will be 
replaced due to changes in the government financing arrangements. This will result in the need 
for extensive safeguard due diligence, environment and climate risk assessments, financial 
management assessments, and economic and financial analyses on the subprojects, which will 
require the support from the TA facility. Accordingly, part of the TA facility will support ADB to 
undertake the due diligence and meet other bank requirements for preparing tranches 2 and 3 of 
the MFF.  
 
3.  Border constraints and untapped mutual benefits. Limited transport connectivity and 
continued disparity of customs inspection, SPS services and clearance processes at key border-
crossing points between Mongolia and the PRC’s neighboring IMAR are constraining Mongolia’s 
international  trade  potential  and  the  development  of  its  remote  borders.  The  RCI  projects 
supported by the facility will address these constraints and spur economic development in 
Mongolia and its border economic zones, as well as generate the economic and employment 
spillover benefits from the project in IMAR. Expanding economic inclusion and crucial services in 
and around IMAR border communities will enhance livelihoods and generate economic gains on 
both sides of the border. These efforts will also contribute to the transport and development goals 
of the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program, especially along its Corridor 4.4 
 
4.  Promoting  regional  public  goods  and  strengthening  coordination.  Effective,

2   
integrated,  long-term  coordination  is  required  between  Mongolia  and  IMAR  to  strengthen 
institutional capacities to address cross-sectoral constraints. Experience shows that coordination 
of multiple public agencies to implement and modernize SPS measures is essential for ensuring 
food safety and the enforcement of health standards for animals and plants transported across 
borders. Introducing new regional approaches to transboundary health risks requires (i) cross-
border coordination mechanisms for policies, regulations, and enforcement mechanisms; (ii) joint 
customs control initiatives; and (iii) greater focus on SPS measures for RCI projects in Mongolia 
and the IMAR. 
 
5.  Need for better design, implementation, monitoring, and reporting. Project design 
and implementation approaches by the line agencies responsible for ADB projects in Mongolia and 
IMAR need to be strengthened and streamlined. Project preparation functions should be optimized, 
the processes better understood, and effective due diligence carried out to achieve sustainable 
results. The TA facility will address these issues through development of effective communication 
plans, implementation monitoring templates, reporting formats, and deliverable records. 
 
6.  Generating better project results. Project implementation has been less than satisfactory 
on both sides of the border, but especially in Mongolia. Poor project management, start-up delays, 
and prolonged implementation are related to government staff’s inexperience and unfamiliarity with 
ADB procedures. Compliance with social and environmental safeguards has also been weak. The 
project preparation activities to be supported by the TA facility will respond to these challenges by 
focusing closely and effectively on quality project design, due diligence, and line agencies’ 
capacity, enabling timely, and successful implementation. 
 
7.  Removing institutional  constraints. Institutional  weaknesses  of  local  governments 
reduce the potential for both countries to benefit from their cross-border cooperation.5 The 
provincial and municipal governments play a major role in managing ADB financed projects in 
IMAR, since they are delegated with the authority to plan and implement investments of national 
and  transnational  significance.6 There are  rising  demands for  local  government  institutional 
capacity as ADB’s cross-border operations are becoming increasingly innovative, multisectoral, 
multidimensional, and are focused on regional and global public goods.7 
 
8.  The TA facility will have three components. The first is to ensure that projects prepared 
through the facility are robustly designed, viable, and design-ready at approval. The second will 
support the timely and effective implementation and long-term sustainability of the results of these 
projects. The third will strengthen the coordination between the two countries to deliver stronger 
regional cooperation project outcomes and promote regional public goods. For Mongolia, the 
projects that the TA facility will support include the (i) Developing the Economic Cooperation Zone 
Project, (ii) Regional Improvement of Border Services, (iii) Regional Upgrades of Sanitary and 
Phytosanitary Measures for Trade, and (iv) Resilient and Integrated Border Services for Safe and 
Fast Trade. For the PRC, the TA facility will support the implementation of the first tranche and 
preparation of the second and third tranche under the Inner Mongolia Sustainable Cross-Border

work undertaken during the preparation of the first tranche of the MFF. It will amplify the 
investment  program’s  strong  design  features  in  promoting  environmental  sustainability  and 
climate change resilience, addressing cross border public health and other risks, and expanding 
direct and spillover benefits to Mongolia.  
 
9.  Alignment with Strategy 2030. The TA facility is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030’s 
Operational Priority (OP) 7 covering (i) greater and higher quality and connectivity between 
economies; (ii) global and regional trade and investment opportunities expanded; and (iii) regional 
public goods increased and diversified, thereby fostering RCI by enhancing connectivity and 
cross-border infrastructure, transforming transport corridors into trade and economic corridors, 
helping the developing member countries participate in regional and global value chains, and 
promoting RPGs by mitigating transboundary risks through SPS measures.9 The TA facility is also 
aligned with OP 6 to strengthen governance and institutional capacities, along with ADB’s country 
partnership strategies for Mongolia and the PRC in increasing environmental sustainability and 
resilience to climate change and disasters. The TA also supports OP 2, accelerating progress in 
gender equality. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
10.  The TA facility, including capacity development during implementation, will promote cross-
border  trade  facilitation,  expand  RPGs  (particularly  those  relating  to  SPS  measures),  and 
enhance cross border connectivity. Special attention will be given to expanding the environment, 
social, and governance features in the projects to be designed and prepared. Tables A2.1 and 
A2.2 in Appendix 2 describe the planned and recently approved RCI projects in Mongolia and the 
PRC that the TA facility will support.  
 
11.  Output  1:  Sound  cross-border  project  preparation  and  regional  public  goods 
promoted. Cross-border synergies between Mongolia and the PRC will maximize the projects’ 
RPG benefits.10 The TA is expected to help develop an investment project to support Mongolia in 
facilitating trade while increasing resilience to transboundary health risks for sustainable recovery. 
The  ensuing  project’s  RPG  component  is  envisaged  to  include:  (i)  provision  of  health 
infrastructure facilities—including testing laboratories—to control the spread of transboundary 
diseases; (ii) establishment of information systems and database for information-sharing among 
border agencies and enhanced integration of systems with regional and global partners, guided 
by a One-Health approach; and (iii) strengthening of institutional capacity for testing, surveillance 
and management at the borders to prevent, detect, and respond quickly to transboundary human 
and animal disease outbreaks. Output 1 activities will also include support to the necessary due 
diligence and other assessments for new subprojects under tranche 2 and 3 of the Inner Mongolia 
Sustainable Cross-Border Development Investment Program. It will help ensure that the projects 
address the transboundary health risks and environmental challenges, particularly desertification

12.  The TA facility will support holistic measures to strengthen project preparation, such as (i) 
the economic, financial, and governance due diligence activities; (ii) the formulation of investment 
plans  and  procurement  packages;  (iii)  assessments  of  the  financial  management  and 
procurement capacity of the executing and implementing agencies; (iv) preparation of strategic 
procurement  planning  documents;  (v)  due  diligence  on  environment,  resettlement,  and 
indigenous peoples in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009); and (vi) an 
assessment of the poverty, gender, and other social development issues related to the project. 
The TA facility will ensure that the ensuing project in Mongolia and subprojects under the tranches 
of  the  Inner  Mongolia  Sustainable  Cross-Border  Development  Investment  Program  are 
economically,  financially,  and  technically  feasible,  and  that  risks  related  to  safeguards  or 
governance are fully identified and mitigated. 
 
13.  Output  2:  Project  implementation  supported.  The  TA  facility  will  strengthen  the 
capacity of the executing and implementing agencies and other entities to implement the RCI 
projects  and  deliver  expected  development  results.  This  will  include  hands-on  project 
management support, training, and mentoring during the implementation of the TA facility-
supported  projects  in  each  country.  Areas  covered  will  include  planning,  preparation, 
implementation, and overall monitoring of the principles, processes, and procedures of ADB 
project design and management. Training will also be provided in consultant recruitment, contract 
management, and supervision, the review of engineering designs and cost estimates, mitigation 
of safeguard risks, and procurement. 
 
14.  Output  3:  Cross-border  coordination  to  deliver  stronger  project  outcomes 
strengthened.  The  TA  facility  will  support  the  institutional  capacity  of  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies in Mongolia and the PRC’s IMAR to design and carry out projects that 
enhance RCI. It will particularly promote institutional interlinkages between the targeted projects 
on both sides of the border and enhance project and policy coordination for more sustainable and 
effective project outcomes. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $1,800,000, of which $200,000 will be provided from 
TASF-7; $800,000 will be provided on a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Fund;11 and $800,000 will be provided on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty 
Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund and administered by ADB.12 The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1. The Government of Mongolia and the Government of the PRC’s 
Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region will provide counterpart support in the form of office space 
and supplies, secretarial assistance, and local transportation. The governments of Mongolia and 
the PRC are aware that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing projects.

17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions. The TA will require 216 person-months of international and national 
consultant  services.  The  consultants  will  prepare  the  ensuing  projects  and  support  the 
implementation and capacity building for all projects supported by this TA. Consultant inputs are 
broken down by expertise, person-months, fund allocations, and country assignment in Table A3. 
Because of the complex and varied nature of the TA components, ADB will determine the most 
efficient method for engaging consulting services. The executing agencies and/or implementing 
agencies of the ensuing projects are expected to exercise ownership during TA implementation, 
with support of the ADB team and consultants. Lumpsum or output-based contracts will be 
considered for consulting services wherever possible, to reduce administrative burden and ensure 
economy and efficiency in the execution of the processes.
